0.355 l bottle from EDEKA Preller (Breckerfeld), bottled in February 2017. Clear, golden yellow with a thin, frothy, almost stable, white head. Sweetish, very fruity, slightly herbal-grassy and a bit resiny aroma of lots of passion fruit, tangerine, mango, orange jam and hints of spruce. Slightly sweetish, moderately bitter, quite fruity, slightly herbal-grassy taste of passion fruit, tangerine, mango and orange jam, followed by a medium long, moderately dry-bitter, herbal-grassy and slightly resiny finish. Medium body, slightly creamy and quite effervescent mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Quite nice, really good balance and still intensely hoppy, decent body for that abv as well.

Clear, dark gold pour with a two finger, loosely frothy off white head. Aroma is citrus, pine, mineral, faint caramel and a hint of sweet tree and berry fruit. Flavor is toast, bread crust, pine, citrus, limestone minerality, a touch of under ripe melon and hints of fresh cut wood. Light body; crisp and a little over the top with hop acid bite, medium, sharp carbonation. Really tasty stuff, not as easygoing as many SIPAs, but it is pretty satisfying and packs a good punch. For those times you want to maximize the feeling of your teeth feeling like hard rubber when they rub together, but minimize alcohol intake.

Gold, nice hops, fruit esters, lemon citrus. Hoppy taste, light easy yet strong finish. Seems bigger, good for the warm weather . Nice hop taste, nice malt, smooth clean simple yet good malt character

12 ounce bottle. Pours a medium gold color topped by a moderate sized frothy white head. Fresh citrus hop aroma has notes of lemon/lime. First sip yields more citrus hops and a decent toasted malt backbone. Malt seems to fade in middle, though flavor is still quite good. Light to medium bodied. Hops are still there in finish, though a bit subdued. Overall, a very good Session IPA that offers immense drinkability with very good balance and flavor.

Appearance: crystal clear pale gold with one fat finger of fluffy white head diminishing gradually to a thin skim, patchy lacing. (4/5) Aroma: bright citrus, pale malt, pine, floral. (7/10) Taste: moderate sweet, moderate bitter. (7/10) Palate: medium-light body tending slightly thin, moderate to soft carbonation, off-dry short duration bitter slightly sharp finish. (3/5)

Initially this seems like its going to be awesome: theres lots of bright citrus hops on the pour, and the lush white head provides a great contrast to the brilliant gold body. Then - well, it doesnt fall apart, as such, but it gets less awesome. Those bright hops fade almost immediately, the lovely head flattens to a cap and then a skim, and the carbonation falls away. More distressingly, the brew starts to feel slightly thin in the body, and finishes with a hint of sharpness. In short, it falls into the trap that so many Session IPAs seem unable to avoid: of having too light a malt bill and too thin a body to support the hop flavours. Now, that being said, its not my intention to be overly harsh with this - its a perfectly serviceable light ale, and would be perfectly fine to have with lunch on a sunny patio. Its just not the lovely hop bomb it starts off smelling like. (14/20)

Taste is light to moderate bitter, light sweet, fruity hops, tangerine, malts, grapefruit. Malty, light bitter aftertaste. Bit thin, not that bitter, maybe bit too old already?

On tap at Owl and Pussycat Taproom and Kitchen (Busan) into a Firestone pint glass. It poured a clear straw gold colour with a one finger white puffy head that had good retention and good lacing. Aromas of citrus grapefruit, light lemon, lime, honey and biscuit malt. Tastes of light citrus, candy grapefruit, biscuit malt, honey and light caramel. Light bodied with moderate carbonation. Overall an easy to drink Session IPA, but perhaps the flavours are not quite my favourite.

Can. Pours a clear gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma combines tropical fruit and grass with a bit of hay and a light int of onion underlying. Flavor has light tropical fruit, some sweet onion, a decent amount of grass and a bit of sweet grain backing.

12oz bottle into a La Chouffe tulip glass on 27th May 2016 while sat in the Californian sun. Looked good, clear golden pour with a white head that wanted to hang around for a while. Nice hop blend in both the nose and flavor with a decent malt base for balance. Liked the alcohol level, afternoon drinking does not need high boosts and this fitted my needs beautifully.

Poured from 12oz can into Spieglau IPA glass, a clear golden colour with huge sudsy white foam, long-lasting with lace. Awesome aromas: honey, flowers, ripe honey dew melon, orange, lemon, grapefruit, pineapple, mango, black currant, pine resin, strawberry. Taste was less good. Thin, almost neutral grainbill, nothing but dank, resiny pot in in the middle...so, if youre into that...
Super-light body, weak mouthfeel, lingering hoppy aftertaste, dry finish. Crisp and thirst-queching, but not as satisfying as Id hoped. This Mandarina, Huell Melon, and Mosaic hop combo smells much better than it tastes.

It was only yesterday that I purchased my 3 cans of Easy Jack. Now Im out. Fuck me, right? I like my Session IPAs so that theyd be easy to confuse with regular IPAs, just with less alcohol. Easy Jack is my shit. Wet sexy hops everywhere in this brew. Guava, pear, pineapple, grapefruit, orange, lemon, lime, mango, tangerine, and subtler notes of pine and caramel malt. Both juicy and zesty fruit notes. Lovely balance of bitterness and malt backbone. This might become a summer mainstay for me... assuming I can keep it around.

bottle shared with a friend. available in our country! thanks to inbev? anyway... poured a deep dark golden colour pour with a white head. nose is very nice, and just the way how i liked it. fruit overdose! sweet peach, stone fruit sweetness, mango, taste follows the nose, balanced fruity. lovely seassion ipa. nice!!

Firestone Easy Jack IPA 4.5%

This gold brew smells heavenly with a huge tropical fruit hop bouquet that features ripe guava, prickly pear and an underlying dank pine. Great.

Light bodied with a very dry scratchy carbonation which makes me wish it was smoother.

The taste is crisply bitter with mild fruit, prickly pear and green pine. Dry finish with a cumulative bitterness. 

This is a solid beer.

355ml bottle. Pours a hazy golden amber, with a moderate off-white head, which lasts reasonably well and leaves decent lacing. The aroma offers melon, lime and floral hops with pleasing fresh white bread malt. Pleasantly bitter grapefruit and lime hops up front segue into fresh melon, which combines with white bread and a touch of caramel in the mid-palate. Floral and melon hops give it a pleasing finish. A very nice session ale.

Can. Pours a clear gold with a foamy sticky finger of white head. Nice floral and citrus aroma. Decent malt front before the hops move in, nice fruity hop finish. Really bright feel, light and crisp, but with enough body to not come off as hop water. The hops and carbonation round off well, making it clean and super easy to down. Well done.

355ml bottle (thanks martjoobolut). Clear golden color. Small size, bubbly white head, stays. Fruity, pine needles, caramelly, malty, sweet in aroma. Fruity, sweet, citrus, caramelly in taste. Fruity and fizzy. Thin body. Drinkable brew.

Light copper with minimal head. Nice citrus, pine, with sharp malt aroma. Taste is more balanced than Im used to from a session IPA - pine & citrus are prominent, but there is more malt balance than expected. The malt character is a bit indistinct, but does add some weight. Mouthfeel is bubbly, with medium bittering finish. Definitely one of the better takes on the sessions.

355ml bottle at home. Clear golden with a medium white soapy head. Light to medium body with low to moderate carbonation. Subtle bitter and sweet tones. Citrus, subtle pine, caramel and malts. Nice session IPA.

Bottle, bottled 02.19.16 (from beergium). Pours golden. Aroma is hoppy, citrus, pineapple, sweetness. Flavor is sweet and bitter, citrus, tangerines. Finish is grapefruit-pine bitter. Body is watery. Overall: OK.

355ml bottle - thanks martjoobolut!
Nice orange, persistentish tight head. Very harsh stinky hop aroma, aggressive. Watery palate. Light malts, some citrussy hop, some bitterness, some snoring. Finish a bit soapy. Very boring pale bitter.

Bottle shared by Mart. Yellowish amber beer, retentive white head. Nose is very citric, fruity, peach, mango, caramel. Flavor is hops forward, lemons, mango, herbal. Some grapefruit and herbal bitterness in the finish. Lingering lemons and grapefruit. Light and fizzy palate.

Tin. Nose is pine, melon, light lime, hints of pineapple. Taste is pineapple, lime, hints of melon, grape, mineral, then a light dry pine finish. There is a good malt body and hints of yeast, and grass.

This is an outstanding session IPA.

Pours a light orange color with decent head. Tropical aromas with a slant towards mandarin. The taste follows the mandarin aroma very closely. A tad of sweetness balances the hops perfectly. Very enjoyable.

Bottle at home. Crystal clear light golden with short lasting white head. Resin, spruce, lime, pineapple, some dried nectarine or peach, soft mineral notes and dry biscuits. Very light sweetness and almost medium bitter. Light bodied with dry feel. Good use of hops!
Bottle. Golden pour. Nice aroma of citrus, grain and mild pine. Fresh taste of citrus, malt, fresh hops, peach and some caramel. Mild hop burn. Very nice and tasty.
Smell is very floral, a little fruit. Taste is more floral, fuggles or goldings floral. hmm ok, not again though.

Can from Aeon Liquors. Big grapefruit dominating nose with orange, pine and mango aromas and a touch of lemon as it warms. Really active carbonation with a light body. Very crisp and clean on the palate. Citrusy and bitter finish, but not astringent. A perfect IPA in a can for summer.
Bottle. Clear orange with a thin white head. Citrus, red peppers, paprika and a bit of honey.
On tap-white head with trailing lace-gold. A-floral/pine. T-floral/pine hops with some bite, lt/slightly sweet malt. With a lingering hop finish.
Fantastic session beer. Combines the smoothness of a pale ale with the assertive citrus freshness of a potent IPA.
Tap at Keyaki. Alright, citrus, malty, biscuit. Nice enough. Few beers down the road at this stage.
Draught at Keyaki. Favorite ipa of the set, light and crisp as it should be, grapefruit, peach, fresh pine, nice dry finish. Could see myself enjoying more of that one for sure.
Easy drinking IPA? Right here. Starts with some wet hay malting, but the hops asserts quite quickly. Not mouth watery, just a nice blend.

Poured from can. 
Aroma is hops, citrus and sweetness. 
Appearance is gold with lacing. 
Tasting a mix of pine, citrus, grass and floral hops with pineapple, yeast, dry malt, hay. 
Palate is dry and refreshing. Great drinkability. 
Overall, one of the best lighter IPAs that Ive tried.

text: Can 12 fl.oz. Poured into a shaker. Pale golden color. Very citrusy, pungent nose slightly sweet nose. Grassy grapefruity mouth medium bitter finish. Pleasant.

Not bad for a session, pours your typical amber from a bottle, nice hop aroma, some tropical fruit, some pine, etc., etc. It just feels like someone cut it with water by half. Probably very refreshing, I just dont see why you wouldnt grab a non-session IPA, which would probably taste slightly better, certainly be more rounded and an overall better experience. Okay beer though.

Draft @ Malmö Öl & Whisky Festival 2016. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity citrus hoppy peachy aroma. Fruity malty citrus hoppy peachy flavor. Has a fruity malty peachy hoppy citrus bitter finish.

Taste has notes of citrusy fruits, herbs, grass, hints of bready malts

Tap @hops&hominy. Gold with white longlasting head and pretty good lacing. Strong citrus and hops aromas with some flowers in the background. Light to medium body, oily. Moderate bitterness with nice finish. Great session ipa.
Very tasty. Nice bitter notes, and grassy aromas. Light and great for a relaxing session.
Tap at Lucky Well. Gold with white head. Big citrus aroma. Flavor not as engaging. Lemony thinner palate. Decent flavor for session.

Can @ Home. Pours golden with an offwhite head. Aroma of malt, grassy hops, flowers, light spice, citrus. Flavor is malt, nice hoppy, grass, spicy, citrus. Medium body, average carbonation, dry and light bitter finish. Nicely refreshing and easy to drink. 230416
Can. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are rich hops, flowers, fruits, malt and citrus. Nice bitter finish.
Can. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Moderate nmalty and hoppy aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. herbal. Average moderate bitter finish. Oily palate.
Can @ Aarhus tasting. Clear golden with a lasting white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - citrus. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 220416
Sweet citrus pine aroma. Clear golden amber body with a white one fingered head. A bitter start with crisp dry finish. A light malt character to smooth out the finish. Drinkable and refreshing.

Bottle from Perfect Pour. Nice amber body with slight head. Nose is hoppy, floral with mango in there. Taste also quite floral with mango and peach falvours. Lots of hops too. Some bitter in the finish. Nice.

355ml can at home shared with mother, from Good Spirits Company, West Nile Street, Glasgow, grassy, pine, tropical fruits aroma, golden with a thin bubbly white head, floral, grapefruit, powdery , very sweet, balanced with a pleasing modern hop finish.

Sampled May 2014
A steady pour into my New Belgium globe glass produces a two finger thick, palely tanned, off-white colored head. The beer is a bright, light honey color that shows a brilliantly clear, bright, yellow-gold hue when held up to the light. The aroma has a huge fruit focus to it with notes of kumquat zest, tangelo zest, guava, a bit of mango, and lychee notes in the first pass. A second pass sees a light spiciness accentuating the fruit character with a suggestion of pepper, as well as a bit of earthy herbal character.

The body is very light, and this is peppered with a zippy, prickly carbonation; there is just enough texture to keep this from being watery, but this is definitely a hot-weather, quaffing type beer. This has a firm, biting bitterness from beginning through to the lingering finish. The bright fruitiness of the nose is reduced in the flavor due to the dryness of this beer, but it is still the biggest contributor. Flavors of Meyer lemon zest, kumquat, tangerine zest, essential guava and lychee, as well as a tropical flower nectar character are all quite present. The bitterness has a bit of pine like character and an herbal edge to it that adds some balance to the fruit character. The malt plays a purely supporting role here, with barely a suggestion of pale malt; more an accentuating hay like character than anything, but, perhaps, at times there is a suggestion of saltine cracker like malt character towards the finish.

This is a nice hoppy Pale Ale; it definitely gives me a needed hop fix, and I like that I can easily through a couple of these back without too much affect.

2014/08/11 - Pours a slightly hazy gold colour with a medium, soapy white head that quickly reduces to a lasting surface film. Moderate lacing. Aroma is big citrus (grapefruite, orange) pine, floral, herbal and slight biscuit malt. Taste is mainly pine, herbal hops and citrus, with mild biscuit and floral notes. Amber pour with an off white head. Nice citrus/floral aromas. Nice light body with a slightly bitter finish. Easy drinker, went down smooth.

Slightly hazy golden with a small head. The aroma is loaded with orange zest, tangerine, resinous pine, and a bit of floral notes. The flavor is similar but more on the resinous side. Nice body and malt character. Slightly bitter.
On draft. Crystal clear golden pour, with a white head. Citrusy, tropical fruit, mango, dry crackery malt, and some bitterness. Nice and clean, but too watery.
On tap at Oskar Blues Restaurant. Very good SIPA (my 2nd favorite behind Founders). Actually more balanced than some others. Zesty aromas.

On draft at Beer Camp. Bright yellow with bright white dissipating head. Clean and clear. Aroma is citrus and floral hops. Malt is light and well balanced with the European hops. Nicely done and highly sessionable.

Bottle in a hotel room in Las Vegas. Clear golden pour, thin white head. Aroma of fruity hops, citrus, some pine and slightly grapefruity. Flavor is fruity bitter hops, very clean and refreshing. Great session ale.

A golden ale with a thin white head. In aroma, sweet orange pulp with light floral hops. In mouth, a nice sweet refreshing citrus ipa with light floral hops, clover field, refreshing. On tap at Piece.

This is a very nice presentation, both aromatically and visually. The liquid is a light yellow-gold with a soft, pure white head that almost took over the glass. It dissipated quickly, leaving a lacing on the glass, sticky and persistent.
The aroma is lightly hoppy, lightly citrus, heavy melon, and almost cough drop-ish in the afterward! This is pleasant, very refreshing and could be one of my favorite sessions.
The finish is nice, long, a little bitter, but just bitter enough. Nothing uncomfortable, rather a nice bite that makes you think of a good pain.
UPDATED: AUG 20, 2014 12 oz bottle, yea this is great! Very light body with a strong citrus hop aroma and grapefruit flavor.
Bottle. simple tropical fruit hops and soft caramel backing. Balance as nice but prefer the no malt character hopped brews as of late. Bitterness in check. Drinkable.

Pours clear yellow with low white head. Aroma of light citrus, pine, light fruit. Taste is light to medium bitter with nice fruit sweet in the finish. Light, smooth body with average carbonation. Just might be the best session IPA Ive had!
On tap. Lots of citrus and pine hop aroma and flavour. This is a great session ipa.

Bottle:   Soft and clean, citrusy with a little pith and peel, and surprisingly very low bitterness.   Lots of flavor, clean, crisp finish.   Sides of the tongue really get the citrus peel and pith, but its not all that bitter.   This would be a great summer quaffer.   Nice!
12oz to snifter. Golden yellow. White head. Thin body. Moderate malt but bright citrusy hops.

Firestone Walkers - Easy Jack separates itself from the Sessionable IPA pack with a citrus hop blend and a balanced malty taste. For me it matches up with Stones Go To IPA - as a step above the Pales, but very accessible IPA.

Appearance: Pours a dull yellow gold. Sparse rising bubbles and a quickly subsided white cap.


Aroma: Tangerine and grapefruit essence. Grassy hops.

Taste: Tangerine, light malt, minerals and that FSW house yeast. Finishes with a quick hop bite.

Mouthfeel: On the thin side of medium bodied. Crisp. Moderate carbonation.

Overall: One of the best Session IPAs currently on the market. Definitely not a one dimensional beer, it had some body, tons of flavor and great IPA like aroma. Not sure if I like this beer or fresh Pale 31 better, perhaps thats like picking your favorite child.

Tasted from draft. Pours a clear gold with white head. Aroma is grapefruit citrus with pine and floral notes. Taste is very piney and peppery. Very muted, some distant mellow pink grapefruit if you search. Easy on the palate, very clean and drinkable. Has some hop character, but nothing pronounced. Draft at Grill Next Door. Pours orange gold with an off white head. Aroma is grapefruit, citrus, pine. Flavor has more citrus and more pine, grapefruit peel bitter in the finish. Good balance overall.
Bright clear golden color. Excellent lacing. Grapefruit aroma, along with other citrus notes. Grassy pine taste. Good session IPA.

Bottle.

A- Grapefruit, tangerines, peaches, juicy.

A- Yellow orange color, clear liquid, white head.

Bottle from Covenhoven. Clean gold with soapy head. Some lacing. Tropical nose, with light caramel behind. Really fresh smelling. Light body of mostly tropical fruit flavors. Minimal malts. Reserved. Mild on all fronts. Easy to drink, but lacks definition.

Draft at Uno Oaks. Shaker pint glass. Pours clear pale straw color with nice head that leaves some lacing. Nose is mild pine and bergamot. First sip is similar with more malt balance than most sIPAs. Finish is very clean ugh mild bitterness. Nice beer.
Bottle from the beer fridge at the lake. Pours a clear yellow with two finger head. Nose is fruit / citrus with a crisp / moderate hop edge....good balance with some malts. Very good session beer.
Bottle from ck1, thanks bro! Hoppy in the nose - heavy grass & fruits. Taste has tons of pine and fresh fruits. And more. Better depth than expected for ABV. This is really tasty! 15.8.
Draft - Sweet grapefruit hops. Clear gold with a nice white head. Nice grapefruit, light bitterness and a clean light finish. Very easy drinking.

Bottle from Capones. Pours bright golden with 2-finger white head that is splotchy and loud, and it says to me, "Respect Fred, you arrogant prick." Well, OK, I needed that. I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip/goblet. It was bottled on 4/14/14 and cost $2.85 ($0.24 per ounce).

Appearance: Straw yellow hue, very hazy but carbonation is visible. Pours to a small, white, foamy head which laces and retains pretty well.

Smell: Strong dry hop aroma of tropical fruit and herbal notes (due to the Mosaic hops Im sure). 

Taste: The American West Coast breweries tend to make great IPAs and double IPAs, though they still havent quite mastered the so-called session IPA yet. Firestone Walker Easy Jack is a good example of what I mean. While its a perfectly fine beer, its not an especially impressive example of the emerging style. 

The description of the brew on the brewerys website indicates a lot of specialty malts were used in brewing this. Its ironic that the base palette is so mild and simple. I get a flavor akin to unsweetened tea, lemon peel and any kind of clear citrusy soda. The hops are of course quite prominent, but are being used for flavor rather than bitterness. They account for the citrus components Im sure, and perhaps a hint of herbal spice, too. I cant help buy find the beer to be a little too mild for its own good, though. Enjoyable for it is, though.

Drinkability: I have mixed feelings on the delivery of Firestone Walker Easy Jack. On one hand the beer is noticeably thin, almost watery, and seems to accentuate the mildness of the brew. On the other hand, it is only 4.5% ABV after all, and its ridiculously easy to drink and is even refreshing for a moment. Theres a slightly dry, lingering aftertaste, but thats washed away by the next swig. If this were drank for its performance value it would definitely perform.

This beer is great. Hoppy as balls and light so you can drink a ton of it. Its weak point might be appearance; its golden orange and clear but w/ a soapy and short lived head. The nose is a huge whallop of hops immediately upon opening the bottle--lots of mango, melon and grapefruit citrus. Heavy bitterness makes this come off bracing and dry as a bone. It drinks a bit bigger than it is but is light bodied enough that you can really quaff it if you have a mind to. This delivers everything youd want from this newly emerging style.

Its light in color, hinting at its thin body and very low caramel malt content. Atop its clear, light golden color is a very airy, bright white head that is the perfect compliment to everything else about the beer. Decorating a basic, clean barley aroma is a fresh, resinous citrus aroma thats gentle, but bold. 

The flavor and mouthfeel are about as perfect as you can get for the style. The dry-hopping was totally necessary here, and reaffirms my belief that almost everything should be dry-hopped. It begins with an acidic, warm tickling of hop delight on the center of the tongue the moment it enters the mouth, followed by an oily coating of that same hop flavor all over the walls of the mouth, finally ending with a fresh, resinous, citrusy, almost coniferous hop-forward finish. Yes, this is all about the hops in the flavor, ans nearly everywhere else. Although its jam packed with hop juice, its not all that bitter. Still, that awesome hop flavor is just enough to make you want to drink this like youd eat a bag of chips. And thats how youre supposed to drink a session IPA.

Tap at Fiddlers Inn. 
Nice to have this one show up so early at Fiddlers. Theyve been serving up some very interesting beers lately. Pours very pale yellow with a modest white head. Grapefruit, quickly backed with the cat-piss-on-onions that I tend to get from Mosaic and also from what is probably Nelson Sauvin. Ive got a sort of love-hate thing going on here; I love the concept but after the first few sips I definitely prefer my glass of icewater. Fortunately, it gets better and better as my palate--or maybe nose--settles in. Full but not overly aggressive bitterness, a small touch of mineral, grapefruit pith, light but not overly thin on the tongue. Its worth a second glass and that one is rich and interesting enough to sip slowly and make last, impressive at 4.5%. I end with mixed feelings. A beer Ill revisit, yes, but Im not sure Ill be glad when I do.

Finish of bitter lemon peel and Warheads sour candies. Off-dry, somewhat husky and astringent malt carried by juicy hops.  It succeeds because the point is Union Jack at 4.5%, and it seems  in line with that minus the strong pine sap and plus a stronger white wine and garlic quality.  Id give it high marks in competition but I wont buy it regularly.

Grabbed a sixer of this. 12 oz bottle pours a bright, clear golden with a fizzy white head and nice lacing. Bready malts, citrusy hops on the nose. Balanced, sweet and hoppy flavor. Clean, well-made. Only nice things to say about this beer.

Bottle - a really balanced and subtle session ipa, with equal emphasis put on the malts, which are soft, bready, lightly sweet - hops are present but balanced, not over the top and assertive, as can often be the case in these beers - lightly peppery, slightly grassy, moderately tropical, with a hint of white grape - immensely quaffable - nice.

On tap at Cheeky Monk. Pour is clear straw with a frothy white head and great lacing. Tropical fruity aroma - orange, mango, and pineapple - ligh grass, biscuit, and straw. Taste is pine, grapefruit peel, straw, oranges, grass, and dough with a medium bitter finish. Fruity and grassy, well-balanced and dry. Great session IPA.

11 day old bottle, pours clear gold with medium white head. Settles quickly with minimal lacing. Aroma is light citrus, piney, floral hops. Flavor is mellow citrus hop, tangerine and orange rind, mildly piney hop finish. Melloww, fruity and sweet hops. Hops were mild but very fresh thanks to the young bottle. Very tasty for a session IPA. Soft carbonation, medium-light body, and a juicy texture. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2015 355ml bottle. 9 days old. Pours a super clear and effervescent light gold, stunning beer. The smell is tropical fruits, citrus, and backing grain. Flavor is acidic and tropical hops, pretty high bitterness for the abv, plenty of bready malt flavors too. It goes down like water, but still waiting for the perfect session ipa. Edit: Drank a ton of this lately, it gets better and better, score raised.

Clear straw yellow with a bright white head and modest lace. Intense grapefruit hop aroma, accompanied by strong pine notes. Extreme hop bitterness with a pleasant offsetting graham cracker-like malt sweetness. Light body, lively carbonation, watery mouthfeel and a crisp finish. Hops are king in this one.

Bottle. Clear gold with a foamy, white head that lasts and laces. Aromas of biscuit, light pine and spice with some citrus. Flavor is pine, spice, biscuit, and some malt. Light to medium bodied. Crisp with a slightly dry finish.
From a tap at Firestone Walker taproom.The pour was pale yellow and had a frothy white head. A lot of citrus hops and is really tasty.perfect for a hot day
